job_title: Oncology Nurse Coordinator in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Good pay and great benefits. Great opportunities for advancement.
cons: Management style varies greatly by department.

pros: Docs are great You might actually feel like you are making a difference Wide variety of patients
cons: Management is like the wild west. One of my current managers got their job without any prior job experience. I've seen another manager scream at a nurse during a case in front of the patient and threaten their job over a situation that was approved by the doctor. Indiana is an at will work state but I still have never experienced management lying to fire someone for no good reason until working here. There are constantly rumors going around. The techs are a tight knit group that aren't welcoming or respectful. They rarely communicate with anyone outside their group, which is usually people with other experience. The head of the group treats everyone else like they are stupid especially if you happen to be forgetful. My training was pretty half assed at best and despite knowing that and being part of that problem, I was still treated like I was an idiot and a waste of breath. There was a time in which I had some words with that person and the way on which they treated me and they ran out of the lab and screamed to everyone that "she doesn't know what she's (fing) doing, she never knows what she's doing". Only when I got in trouble for something and then turned around and let management know I knew a lot of the things said about me and other people's completely unacceptable behavior did they care to try and change things. I would come into work, immediately start working while the rest of the techs are breakfast, socialized, completely ignored me. I stopped stocking for a while and noticed what a big difference that made. I was taken advantage of by people who constantly degraded me behind my back and made me seem unworthy of respect in others eyes. It really feels like there is little to no self reflection from certain people here, but those same people love to say the worst things about others. It seems like management here is completely ok with people who are selfish brats with little to no experience running the place. The more people I have talked to about who has worked here and left the more I know- that's exactly why everyone has left. You are treated like garbage and your job isn't even secure. Management doesn't have your back.

Insane micromanagement like I've never experiences before, they count how long you take in the bathroom and you can't take time to talk to supervisors or coworkers even if it is work-related. Everyone in the organization is overworked and underpaid, we have stayed this long because of the patients but the management is getting so bad, a lot of employees have decided to leave.

review_title: Excellent place to gain invaluable experience, but could use improvement to combat burnout
pros: Competitive pay scale and decent incentives! Nurse/patient ratios in place. Management is willing to jump in and help out bedside nurses. Managers reach out to nursing staff for input to improve overall morale.
cons: Y'all have got to come up with a practical solution for lunch breaks, and if you can't.... then stop automatically deducting a 30-minute lunch from your staff. You cannot reasonably expect people to work continuously for 12.5 hours without any sort of uninterrupted break. The patient population is notoriously difficult, demanding, and overwhelmingly entitled. Patient care techs, who serve an extraordinarily important role, are insufficiently staffed. This often results in an overwhelmed, over-worked tech along with the nurse trying to oversee total-assist feeds, bathing, changing, linen changes, and a multitude of other tasks while simultaneously trying to pass meds on time, complete vitals, report abnormal results to teams, oversee discharges/admissions, and complete procedures (i.e. lab draws, EKGs, IV placement, pre-op checklists, etc.) Typically, my working relationship with the doctors and PT/OT/ST has been satisfactory, but med students are definitely on the arrogant/rude side. They'll come in long enough to promise your patient the moon and the stars, only to never be seen again. The point system is a little rigid in terms of how PTO can be used, especially since most of us don't schedule or plan our illnesses in advance.

pros: The benefits can be good

review_title: Solid employer that has some tweaks to work out with staffing
pros: Excellent training. Very in-depth and Human Resources staff was friendly and efficient. Professional development was readily available and encouraged. Opportunity to move around. I met a lot of wonderful caregivers that had many years invested with Eskenazi. Pay was ok. Huge staff but efforts were regularly made to thank staff for our work.
cons: Paperwork tracking client status and progress was illustrated in training by Eskenazi. Staff was later made to feel responsible for lost revenue for reports submitted and rejected (not being paid). Budget overhaul and efficiency studies made many people uncomfortable. Unclear if staff positions were removed randomly or stategically. My position was one that was downsized.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse II in Indianapolis, IN
pros: The hospital NICU was a great place for our babies to be, HOWEVER.....there are many wonderful hosptals that are great.  I stayed because i loved my babies, but the only absolute area I would insist that everyone I LOVE should choose  WISHARD/ESKENAZI IS THE EMERGENCY AREA....level one first rate place to be if you are faced with an emergent situation.   Any other hospitalization required.....RUN to any other hospital available.
cons:
Poor communication between supervisors and staff. No trust or loyalty to the older nurses who were excellent but not always as quick as the new grads.  Gossip, and malicious activity in order to advance careers was the disease that spread throughout the New Beginnings floor. LPNS were watched by all......any slip..any wrong move..any possible reason to declare them no longer competent to work on the units. So after 20 years of devotion to our babies and having had an excellent reputation as a hardworking team member, it seemed day by day the unit seemed different. I knew my time at the hospital was ending...AND WITH THE OPENING OF THE G-R-E-A-T ESKENAZI HOSPITAL IN SITE.......THE LPN'S WERE NO LONGER WANTED OR NEEDED.  i WAS IN A POSITION TO BE DRIVEN AWAY, SO............RETIRED!!!
e

job_title: Revenue Cycle Auditor in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Healthy food, wellness options for employees, farmers market
cons: Unprofessional, disrespectful environment.  Leadership training isn't applied and employees are heavily micro managed.  If you have an opinion, or provide ANY feedback that they do not agree with you will become a target and there will be retaliation.  They lie to you to make you believe they are a family, but they are the furthest from that type of environment.  The click which is leadership and a few pets may be family, but they treat everyone else horribly.  I shared that the productivity measures were too high and was told that I had a time management issue... their favorite employee tells them the same thing and automatically a reduction is sent to the team to review.

review_title: Overall - a great hospital that actually serves the under served.  They don't just CLAIM they do they DO it!!
pros: Provides services to every patient equally of socio-economic standing.  Has many programs offered to community however the system is flooded.  As a nurse I feel like I'm doing a great job to for our patients.  Many of the staff work together as a TEAM.
cons: With the system being flooded it takes a while for patients to get seen and commonly that is a complaint.  However, having the opportunity to have services is the first key.  Refining is the next goal- currently being worked on.

pros: Physcians are great! It's just the nurses you hv to go through to get to them.
cons: Extreme nepotism in the work place. The outpatient clinical  neglect is extremely stressful. If you're cold hearted and don't care abt patients and need leadership to support you with that, this is your place.

job_title: RN Case Manager in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Good benefits, many opportunities for mobility within the organization.
cons: The benefits used to be great.  The case management leadership team has unrealistic job expectations.  Primary leadership style is intimidation and bullying.  This absolutely the most dysfunctional management team that I have ever worked for  and it starts with the Director.   The average case manager works 10-12 hrs daily.  Position requirements don't allow time for lunch. Positions are salary and you are constantly reminded of that.  Employment in this department doesn't allow for any work life balance.

pros: All I can say is WOW!! Eskenazi is such a great place to work. Eskenazi offers great dental, vision, and health insurance, as well as 401k matching, tuition reimbursement, generous paid time off, free work out facility... and the list goes on and on! The  senior management is truly invested in your career and cares about your happiness within the organization. My supervisor and manager really partner with me to make sure I am successful and happy in my role. Everyone is like a family here and the culture is unmatched to anywhere I have ever been before.  At Eskenazi, you really feel like you are serving a greater purpose rather than just coming to work. It keeps me motivated each day!
cons: None that I can think of.

job_title: Senior IT Project Manager in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Facilities are wonderful as is the attitude of the employees
cons: I served as a Senior IT Project Manager at Eskenazi Health for a short period of time and I would offer a caution to potential employees.  My short employment was precipitated by a WIDE gap between the description of the position in the job requisition and reality.  This could have easily been avoided with a truthful job requisition which would have been in the best interest of both the prospective employee and Eskenazi Health by saving both parties time and revenue.  My suggestion to the prospective employee  is to strongly question the job description during the interview process and do not make ANY assumptions based on the job requisition (this occurrence seemed very ironic for a hospital, non-profit).

review_title: The absolute worst place I've ever worked
job_title: Financial Eligibility Department in Indianapolis, IN
pros: They are a PERF employer (public employee retirement fund)
cons:
-The management team is horrible. 
-Employees are talked to and treated like children.
-HR and executive management allows such behavior.
-Training is non-existent...management is much more concerned with schooling you on their demeaning childish rules then they are with teaching you how to complete your duties well.  On second thought they're not even capable of training because they've never taken the time to learn the job themselves.
-Work environment obviously sucks because of the inhumane way people are treated.

review_title: Great mission and intentions, mediocre pay
pros: Organization's dedication to serving underserved communities in Indianapolis. Beautiful campus. Decent health coverage if you get care within the system (but fairly high deductible otherwise).
cons: Fairly low pay (they're a safety net health system) for non-MDs/PharmDs, who brought home eye-popping salaries. They'd wax poetic about how vital care coordinators and social workers were but then paid us a tiny fraction of what the higher-ups made. Very little opportunity for advancement if you don't have an MD. My department (infectious disease clinic) had really high levels of burnout and turnover.

review_title: Everyone gets thrown in because everyone is always quitting. This is for Eskenazi Midtown by the way.
pros: I like my Supervisor.  I have coached her how to support me and she is very good most of the time.
cons: Low pay. Poor emplyee/boss relationship. Limit resources.  Management focused now on only making sure they get paid. You are a number and a poorly trained number. Too many managers and supervisors which creates red tape, distrust, politics,  and also managers treat you like children despite your age and experience.

review_title: The focus is on great patient care
pros: Multidisciplinary approach to patient care, several opportunities for interactions with senior management, friendly staff - many have been there for years and take pride in what they do. They have a great mission to Advocate, Teach and Serve with an emphasis on the under-served population of Indianapolis. All of the employees know the mission and take it to heart when performing their jobs.
cons: CPOE system and the process for updating/improving the system, education of the medical residents regarding the different IT systems at the hospital and hospital policies and procedures..most of this is done by the staff during "real time" while also taking care of patients.

pros: Personal and professional growth opportunity, diversity, value your contribution, company invests in making it a positive work environment. Pushing hard to promote those that continued education while employed with them.
cons: The patient population is diverse but because they are a county hospital and publicly funded, you will see many patients that do not buy into their own health care or provider advice. Generally most areas are competitive pay- this position included but not with all employees.

pros:
Benefits-Great insurance, Paid vacation days, and retirement benefits
I love my coworkers, and the clients I work with.
The work I do is really fulfilling for me.
cons:
The pay is really not great for a person with a bachelor's degree. I understand I'm in the human services field, but a living wage would be preferable. 
Utilization and productivity are pushed really hard-it is the only way they measure an employees "worth" to the company.
Very high caseloads, and many people leave.

pros: They seem to really care for their employees, they feel strongly about wellness and have many ways to help you if you wish to improve or change things about your well being. Everyone is friendly, they work with you for family emergencies and illness.
cons: Not sympathetic or understanding of a smoking habit. Senior employees are not as educated for their positions, they seem to keep people out of favor rather than job performance. Employees are not given much consideration for personal time.

review_title: Wonderful team, good pay, poor working conditions (at times)
pros: The supervisors at Eskenazi work very hard to ensure that Care Coordinators are being hired onto teams that compliment their strengths as so much work in done in a team setting. I believe this helps employees grow as well as benefits clients for their whole treatment team is stronger and more knowledgeable about resources in the community. I found the pay to be fair, especially as Care Coordinators are often people with BSW's or Bachelor Degrees with some related work history such as criminal justice, political science, or perhaps something in public health.
cons: There are satellite clinics outside of the hospital, the immediate care clinics as well as all of the Eskenazi Midtown Community Mental Health Centers. These centers are strategically located within the communities of Indianapolis that need them most but often lack amenities for the employees. Parking was often not to be found which could have jeoparized job time; imagine coming back from a home visit with a client but not being able to park at your own building, or on the street, or even within two-three blocks of the building. It would have been a dream to work at the hospital and have access to the cafeteria, the wellness center, the classes offered, etc. The hours at the smaller clinics do not allow employees access to these facilities unless you jeopardize taking time off instead of getting your required monthly hours. At my location, we also did not have consistent janitorial staff and with our population, this often meant bodily fluids were spilled, restrooms were smeared with feces or urine, and the employees do not have a separate area for lunch breaks, etc which ensures that we are accessed at all times, even when we need our break.

pros: The management is very flexible with scheduling.  They also strive to keep a good work/life balance for you.  Benefits are AMAZING! (see tuition reimbursement and retirement first).
cons: Clientele served are often underprivileged, addicted, manipulative and entitled.  This makes for challenging situations that don't need to be challenging.  Management DOES back you up though!

review_title: Gained absolutely nothing from my time there.
job_title: Security Officer II in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Take home equipment. Excellent benefits. A few good coworkers here and there. Good pay with good shift premiums. Twelve hour shifts.
cons: Management sets you up for failure. They will put you in impossible situations and then write you up for failing. If you come from another healthcare facility, they will be prejudiced against you, disrespect you, and withhold training opportunities from you to prevent you from excelling. They are corrupt.

pros:

Leadership touchable
cons:
5- day, 40-hour work week for Clinic Staff.
Have to use PTO for personal appts.
Allow outpatient nurses who have inpatient experience to "pick up" at the hospitals if they want to.

review_title: Great organization for someone wanting to start their careers
pros:
-Caring and open Senior Leadership Team
- Everyone wants to help everyone succeed
-Good benefits
cons:

-Pay structure could be more competitive and/or transparent.

review_title: Wishard has a firm grasp on current public health initiatives and is a valuable asset to central Indiana.
job_title: Spanish Medical Interpreter in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Great sense of community. A chance to work with very caring and motivated people. Opportunity to train and grow within the organization.
cons: Some co-workers are undertrained and unprofessional. Encouragement is rarely given and there is a sense that co-workers are out to get each other.

pros: Benefits are great. Eskenazi follows it mission closely and values self-care. Eskenazi employees that are on campus have a lot of great resources.
cons: Compensation is not great. If you don't work on campus access to self-care activities, such a gym, fitness classes, and wellness coach, can be a challenge.

review_title: I have been working as an RN on the med surg unit since May '16 and love the experience, fellow nurses, and management.
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Indianapolis, IN
pros: I have a set schedule, opportunities to pick up additional shifts and trade with other nurses as needed. very flexible!
cons: The patient population is a tough group sometimes so that has been an adjustment. Sometimes the turnover for patients is quick so discharging and admitting can become a huge part of your day.

pros: I wanted to work for the county hospital to help the community receive excellent healthcare. That is often a common goal among coworkers.
cons: The leadership at Eskenazi does not take accountability for problems or improvement. When there is a system failure, it is often not discussed, only good news is shared at meeting, thus, never getting to the root of the problem.  Several nursing leaders are consistently  unapproachable and confrontational, establishing a poor culture for collaboration. I also left with reporting to HR of an offensive supervisor, who regularly insulted the patients and coworkers based on race, nationality, and religion with no resolution.

pros:
Company does fun events & employee recognition
Great team work
Support for continuing education
Flexible
Good benefits
Good PTO
cons:
Too many changes
Increased pressure & demand
Very high expectations
Stressful schedule management (double booking)

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Co-workers were nice, we were able to work together well.
cons: Management not knowledgeable , they hire people with business degrees to manage medical staff. Equipment is outdated , computer system crashes frequently. Care is not provided in a timely manner because staffing levels are so low. Patients sit and wait hours for care.

pros: Decent Benefits. Discount for employees dining at the hospital or 38th street location. There were a small handful of upper management that treated their people with respect, and their people would follow them to the ends of the earth.
cons: The Executive level closes their eyes to the problems they have with their direct reports. Some of their direct reports have time management, focus or anger problems, but they are never addressed. It's just one crisis after another in the headquarters (FOB) as well as in the clinics. No one of any value will stay for any length of time because none of the management in the company seems to know how to make positive change. Then they brought in a woman who motivates with sticks instead of carrots in the clinics and it was like a big ol' conga line as the staff quit their jobs. Then a high ranking executive left, and I realized it was time to go. He was the last person that listened to the peons and actually valued their "boots on the ground" opinion. This place embodies the "peter principle". The executives have surrounded themselves with "yes men" and run the "independent thinkers" out of the company.

pros: The organization is open to new ideas, they are flexible and everyone is always there to help if you need assistance.
cons: The only thing I can think of is only getting a 30 min lunch.

review_title: Patient Customer Service Supervisor-assisting patient with patient inquiries

pros: Love the patient population and the challenges they bring to your job every day. There are great benefits as healthy me , gym inside the facilities and yoga and cardio classes.

cons: I have not ran into a con yet. I love working for this place!!

pros: Decent pay. Great benefits and
cons: Terrible management. Poor attitudes and no morale. Favortism and management needs training.
